prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Correlator set up: We wish to observe the 12CO 2-1, 13CO 2-1, C18O 2-1, and dust continuum simultaneously in band 6. The expected linewdiths of the sources are ~3 km/s or 2.7MHz. Thus, we can acquire all observations together by using, in TDM mode, the correlator set up with 117 MHz bandwidth, 60 kHz channel width (0.08 km/s resolution) for the line observations, and with 2GHz bandwidth, 31 MHz channel with for the dust continuum at 1mm. We will smooth the spectra by 8 channels to reduce data rates and maintain < 0.5 km/s spectral resolution. The 13CO and C18O observation will fit in the LSB, while the 12CO and dust continuum will fit in the USB.

In the SMC, we want to resolve the pc scale structure of CO emission, which at 62 kpc distance is 3". We expect CO emission to extend on 1' scales. Thus we request a resolution of 3" and LAS of 1'. Our observations can therefore be performed in the most compact configuration of the 12 m array (best resolution of 1.62"). For this configuration, the maximum recoverable scale (MRS) is 11.4". Since the CO emission extends on scales larger than the MRS, the use of the ACA is required, to probe scales as large as 18". This is not sufficient to cover the extent of CO clouds in the SMC. Therefore, we request total power array observations as well. Simulations performed with Casapy confirm that both the fine-scale structure and the extended emission are recovered with this set up. We will obtain square mosaics 1' in side.

Sensitivity: Assuming thermalized optically thick emission at 5 K (lower limit), the TMB(12CO 2-1) main beam temperature will be > 5 K. Assuming a typical main beam temperature ratio of 10 for the 12CO/13CO, the TMB(13CO 2-1) will be > 0.5 K. This transition is crucial to derive accurate column densities and drives the S/N. Typical linewidths are 3 km/s and we will therefore bin the spectrum up to 1 km/s. We request S/N ~ 10 on the 13CO 2-1 transition, and therefore request a sensitivity of 0.05 K (20 mJy) per 3" beam per 1 km/s.
Previous Herschel observations yield an expected continuum flux density of 5 mJy. The proposed sensitivity will give us S/N >20 on the observations of the 1mm dust emission continuum.

Correlator set up: We wish to observe the 12CO 2-1, 13CO 2-1, C18O 2-1, and dust continuum simultaneously in band 6. The expected linewdiths of the sources are ~3 km/s, or 2.7MHz. Thus, we can acquire all observations together by using, in TDM mode, the correlator set up with 117 MHz bandwidth, 60 kHz channel width (0.08 km/s resolution) for the line observations, and with 2GHz bandwidth, 31 MHz channel with for the dust continuum at 1mm. We will smooth the spectra by 8 channels to reduce data rates and maintain < 0.5 km/s spectral resolution. The 13CO and C18O observation will fit in the LSB, while the 12CO and dust continuum will fit in the USB.

In the LMC, we want to resolve the pc scale structure of CO emission, which at 50 kpc distance is 3". We expect CO emission to extend on 1' scales. Thus we request a resolution of 3" and LAS of 1'. Our observations can therefore be performed in the most compact configuration of the 12 m array (best resolution of 1.62"). For this configuration, the maximum recoverable scale (MRS) is 11.4". Since the CO emission extends on scales larger than the MRS, the use of the ACA is required, to probe scales as large as 18". This is not sufficient to cover the extent of CO clouds in the SMC. Therefore, we request total power array observations as well. Simulations performed with Casapy confirm that both the fine-scale structure and the extended emission are recovered with this set up. We will obtain square mosaics 1' in side.

Sensitivity: Assuming thermalized optically thick emission at 5 K (lower limit), the TMB(12CO 2-1) main beam temperature will be > 5 K. Assuming a typical main beam temperature ratio of 10 for the 12CO/13CO, the TMB(13CO 2-1) will be > 0.5 K. This transition is crucial to derive accurate column densities and drives the S/N. Typical linewidths are 3 km/s, and we will therefore bin the spectrum up to 1 km/s. We request S/N > 10 on the 13CO 2-1 transition, and therefore request a sensitivity of 0.05 K (20 mJy) per 3" beam per 1 km/s.
Previous Herschel observations yield an expected continuum flux density of 5 mJy. The proposed sensitivity will give us S/N >20 on the observations of the 1mm dust emission continuum.

Correlator set up: We wish to observe the 13CO 1-0 and C18O 1-0 simultaneously in band 3. The expected linewdiths of the sources are ~3. Thus, we can acquire all observations together by using, in TDM mode, the correlator set up with with 117 MHz bandwidth for the line observations. We will smooth the spectra by 4 channels to reduce data rates and maintain < 0.5 km/s spectral resolution. The 13CO and C18O observation will both fit in the USB. We set the LSB window to observce the CS 2-1 line, which will serve as a tracer of dense star forming gas. Another dust continuum window fits in the LSB and will provide an additional data point in the dust SED.

In the SMC, we want to resolve the pc scale structure of CO emission, which at 62 kpc distance is 3". We expect CO emission to extend on 1' scales. Thus we request a resolution of 3" and LAS of 1'. Our observations can therefore be performed in the most compact configuration of the 12 m array. For this configuration, the maximum recoverable scale (MRS) is 30". Since the CO emission extends on scales larger than the MRS, the use of the ACA is required. This is not sufficient to cover the extent of CO clouds in the SMC. Therefore, we request total power array observations as well. Simulations performed with Casapy confirm that both the fine-scale structure and the extended emission are recovered with this set up. We will obtain square mosaics 1' in side.

Sensitivity: Assuming thermalized optically thick emission at 5 K (lower limit), the TMB(12CO 1-0) main beam temperature will be > 5 K. Assuming a typical main beam temperature ratio of 10 for the 12CO/13CO, the TMB(13CO 1-0) will be > 0.5 K. This transition is crucial to derive accurate column densities and drives the S/N. Typical linewidths are 3 km/s, and we will therefore bin the spectrum up to 1 km/s. We request S/N > 10 on the 13CO 1-0 transition, and therefore request a sensitivity of 0.05 K (5 mJy) per 3" beam per 1 km/s.

Correlator set up: We wish to observe the 13CO 1-0 and C18O 1-0 simultaneously in band 3. The expected linewdiths of the sources are ~3. Thus, we can acquire all observations together by using, in TDM mode, the correlator set up with with 117 MHz bandwidth for the line observations. We will smooth the spectra by 4 channels to reduce data rates and maintain < 0.5 km/s spectral resolution. The 13CO and C18O observation will both fit in the USB. We set the LSB window to observce the CS 2-1 line, which will serve as a tracer of dense star forming gas. Another dust continuum window fits in the LSB and will provide an additional data point in the dust SED.

In the LMC, we want to resolve the pc scale structure of CO emission, which at 50 kpc distance is 3". We expect CO emission to extend on 1' scales. Thus we request a resolution of 3" and LAS of 1'. Our observations can therefore be performed in the most compact configuration of the 12 m array. For this configuration, the maximum recoverable scale (MRS) is 30". Since the CO emission extends on scales larger than the MRS, the use of the ACA is required. This is not sufficient to cover the extent of CO clouds in the SMC. Therefore, we request total power array observations as well. Simulations performed with Casapy confirm that both the fine-scale structure and the extended emission are recovered with this set up. We will obtain square mosaics 1' in side.

Sensitivity: Assuming thermalized optically thick emission at 5 K (lower limit), the TMB(12CO 1-0) main beam temperature will be > 5 K. Assuming a typical main beam temperature ratio of 10 for the 12CO/13CO, the TMB(13CO 1-0) will be > 0.5 K. This transition is crucial to derive accurate column densities and drives the S/N. Typical linewidths are 3 km/s, and we will therefore bin the spectrum up to 1 km/s. We request S/N > 10 on the 13CO 1-0 transition, and therefore request a sensitivity of 0.05 K (5 mJy) per 3" beam per 1km/s.

Correlator set up: We wish to observe the 12CO 1-0 and dust continuum simultaneously in band 3. The expected linewdiths of the sources are ~3 km/s. Thus, we can acquire all observations together by using, in TDM mode, the correlator set up with with 117 MHz bandwidth for the line observations. We will smooth the spectra by 4 channels to reduce data rates and maintain < 0.5 km/s spectral resolution.

In the SMC, we want to resolve the pc scale structure of CO emission, which at 62 kpc distance is 3". We expect CO emission to extend on 1' scales. Thus we request a resolution of 3" and LAS of 1'. Our observations can therefore be performed in the most compact configuration of the 12 m array. For this configuration, the maximum recoverable scale (MRS) is 30". Since the CO emission extends on scales larger than the MRS, the use of the ACA is required. This is not sufficient to cover the extent of CO clouds in the SMC. Therefore, we request total power array observations as well. Simulations performed with Casapy confirm that both the fine-scale structure and the extended emission are recovered with this set up. We will obtain square mosaics 1' in side.

Sensitivity: Assuming thermalized optically thick emission at 5 K (lower limit), the TMB(12CO 1-0) main beam temperature will be > 5 K. Typical linewidths are 3 km/s, and we will therefore bin the spectrum up to 1 km/s. We request S/N > 20 on the 12CO 1-0 transition, and therefore request a sensitivity of 0.25 K (25 mJy) per 3" beam per 1 km/s. The S/N for this transition (S/N = 20) is higher than for the other optically thin transitions because these observations are dominated by overheads and the difference between S/N of 10 and 20 in terms of total time is minuscule. We therefore will benefit from higher quality maps for practically no additional observing cost.

Correlator set up: We wish to observe the 12CO 1-0 and dust continuum simultaneously in band 3. The expected linewdiths of the sources are ~3 km/s. Thus, we can acquire all observations together by using, in TDM mode, the correlator set up with with 117 MHz bandwidth for the line observations. We will smooth the spectra by 4 channels to reduce data rates and maintain < 0.5 km/s spectral resolution.

In the LMC, we want to resolve the pc scale structure of CO emission, which at 50 kpc distance is 3". We expect CO emission to extend on 1' scales. Thus we request a resolution of 3" and LAS of 1'. Our observations can therefore be performed in the most compact configuration of the 12 m array. For this configuration, the maximum recoverable scale (MRS) is 30". Since the CO emission extends on scales larger than the MRS, the use of the ACA is required. This is not sufficient to cover the extent of CO clouds in the SMC. Therefore, we request total power array observations as well. Simulations performed with Casapy confirm that both the fine-scale structure and the extended emission are recovered with this set up. We will obtain square mosaics 1' in side.

Sensitivity: Assuming thermalized optically thick emission at 5 K (lower limit), the TMB(12CO 1-0) main beam temperature will be > 5 K. Typical linewidths are 3 km/s, and we will therefore bin the spectrum up to 1 km/s. We request S/N > 20 on the 12CO 1-0 transition, and therefore request a sensitivity of 0.25 K (25 mJy) per 3" beam per 1 km/s. The S/N for this transition (S/N = 20) is higher than for the other optically thin transitions because these observations are dominated by overheads and the difference between S/N of 10 and 20 in terms of total time is minuscule. We therefore will benefit from higher quality maps for practically no additional observing cost.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: The star formation rate is proportional to the surface density of molecular gas, for a wide range of metallicities. Models predict that the structure of CO-emitting gas should change with metallicity and radiation field: extended CO emission and CO "clumps" should shrink as metallicity decreases or radiation field strength increases. This effect has never been directly observed before, and models of CO formation have not been put to a test. Additionally, the effects of those changes on the star formation process, which occurs in dense, CO-emitting gas, are unknown. We propose to obtain deep maps of two transitions (1-0 and 2-1) of three CO isotopes (12CO, 13CO, and C18O) in 6 regions of two low-metallicity galaxies, the LMC and the SMC. These observations will allow us to test CO photo-chemical models by providing deep maps of the pc-scale structure, column density, thermal, and chemical state of the CO-emitting gas at two low metallicities and a range of radiation fields. By comparing the CO maps to pc-resolution tracers of star formation, specifically 24 micron emission and young stellar objects, we will bridge the gap between Galactic and extragalactic star formation studies
